Topic.Title: The evolution of the government 'safety net'

Message.Msg: When I began construction work building metal buildings, some 10' high to a grain elevetaor 200' high, I never even heard of safety ropes, our safety equipment consisted of a pair of steel toed boots & fiber glass helmet and that was left up to the indivual. Pulling steel and working off the ground was just part of the job. I was looking for a job and saw a building going up, stopped my car and asked for a job, I had no experience. I did not tell the foreman I could not watch or participate and leave, I told him I would report for work the next day at 6am because I needed the money, so you must not have needed the money as much as me. I moved to another state and got on a building crew and they wore safety ropes etc. I laughed at them, those ropes reduce productivity, you know.

Topic.Title: The evolution of the government 'safety net'

Message.Msg: I crawled the beams for a few months and creates a lot of bruises and makes you tired, finally after suffering crawling I just got up and walked, much easier on your #$%$. That was one of my first jobs so I literally started on the ground floor, they worked me on the ground for about a week and finally the foreman asked me if I was ready to go "UP". Going up for the 1st time is like getting your 1st girl, you never forget.

Topic.Title: PC sales down 21%, MSFT Windows & Office sales will be down 21%

Message.Msg: There is one thing about PC sales being down that is seldom mentioned, and deserves a closer look, but I haven't analyzed it. That 21% was US sales and dragged down worldwide sales which were down less (in a worldwide down economy), and there could have a seldom mentioned reason for US sales being down. In 2011 in the US, I heard, there was a very good investment tax incentive to buy PC's in that year. Like many programs over the last number of years, it robbed sales from the future. Couple that with an foreseen upcoming launch of Win8, worldwide weak economies and I could see a fall off ... at least it is a consideration. And it is not surprising that people spend their "rationed money" on phones and tablets when those are the things they may not have already, and are the hype. MSFT has just now started to be in that game. The Win8 launch over all platforms is going to be drawn out, and the launch almost seemed convoluted, but I don't know how that could have been avoided unless MSFT just delayed the launch. INTC will eventually get their chips for tablets and phones out with LTE ... and the many manufacturers will eventually offer the new products. It's just going to be drawn out. Plenty of time for bashing and hype. Both sides can have their fun. But MSFT has started to unfold things and others have a new competitor ... we'll see how the future unfolds. I could see the BYOW starting to weaken over the next few years.

Topic.Title: Msft should spin Office off

Message.Msg: Sun and Oracle dropped support for Star Office but still include it with the Solaris operating system. Then Star Office went to a open source development. And Word Perfect is available. Then Google developed a following for its office applications. So a lite version of MS Office has become just a necessary part of the operating system for consumers. But MS doesn't need to buy the product to add it to the operating system. Then MS puts silly ads into the consumer version. But desktop applications should not have ads but only webpages can have ads. But most companies still need the full version of MS Office.
